Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the parent should attend
Situation2: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Story: I glanced at the calendar on the fridge, my daughter’s open class circled in bright red marker. She’d been talking about it for weeks, her eyes shining with hope every time she asked, “Will you come, Mom?” I wanted nothing more than to be there, to watch her proudly show off her reading skills. But as I looked around the living room, the mess from the morning rush stared back at me—crumbs on the carpet, toys scattered, dust gathering on the shelves. My job as a housekeeping cleaner meant I was expected to keep everything spotless, especially since the landlord was coming by for an inspection that afternoon. I knew if I left now, the house would still look lived-in, not the pristine standard I was supposed to maintain. My heart tugged in two directions: the promise I made to my daughter, and the responsibility I owed to my work. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, cleaning spray in the other, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing down on me.
